thread.title: Treasurys Extend Recent Gains

author: Sam Goldfarb
title: Treasurys Extend Recent Gains
text:
0 COMMENTS U.S. government bond prices traded in a narrow range Friday, ending the U.S. session slightly higher, as investors paused after trade tensions sent them flocking to Treasurys a day earlier.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury note settled at 3 p.m. at 2.826%, compared with 2.832% Thursday and 2.848% a week earlier.
Yields, which fall when bond prices rise, fell sharply Thursday along with stocks as the Trump administration said it would impose tariffs on Chinese imports, prompting retaliatory plans from China. Investors tend to buy Treasurys during times of economic uncertainty because they offer steady interest payments and essentially no credit risk.
The U.S. Treasury Building in Washington. Photo: Stephen Voss for The Wall Street Journal On Friday, Treasurys pulled back a little after President Donald Trump signed a bill to fund the government until October, ending speculation that there could be a government shutdown. That move, however, quickly reversed as stocks fell again, reflecting what analysts described as general unease in the market.
Investors are fairly confident in the economy and the direction of monetary policy from the Federal Reserve, but “the wild card is coming from the White House,” said Larry Milstein, head of government and agency trading at R.W. Pressprich & Co.
“The question is, on any day, you don’t know what’s going to happen.”
Investors turned their attention to trade and politics after the Fed on Wednesday increased its benchmark federal-funds rate by 0.25 percentage point and raised its median forecast to three rate increases in 2019 from two.
Treasury yields have jumped this year partly because investors have grown more concerned that a sustained period of economic growth across developed countries will finally result in higher inflation and a move to tighter monetary policies around the globe. Inflation is a threat to government bonds because it erodes the purchasing power of their fixed payments.
Still, recent data has suggested that inflation in the U.S. is still relatively muted, helping ease pressure on Treasurys after the 10-year yield nearly reached 3% in February.
